name.text: Finding the Area of a Regular Pentagon

questiontext.text:
Find the area of the figure below, centered at O, and round your answer to the nearest \(\textbf{whole number}\).

[[jsxgraph]] var board = JXG.JSXGraph.initBoard(divid, { boundingbox: [-6, 6, 6, -6], axis: true, showCopyright: false }); /* Centre */ var C = board.create('point', [{@cx@}, {@cy@}], { name: 'C', fixed: true }); /* First vertex */ var A = board.create('point', [ {@cx@} + {@R@}, {@cy@} ], { name: 'A', fixed: true }); /* Regular pentagon */ var pentagon = board.create('regularpolygon', [C, A, 5], { withLines: true, withVertices: true }); [[/jsxgraph]]

\(\text{Area} =\)[[input:ans1]]\(\text{cm}^2\) [[feedback:prt1]]

[[validation:ans1]]

generalfeedback.text:
The figure above is a regular isosceles pentagon

Each triangle has

  • \(\text{Base} = \frac{{@base_length @}}{2}={@half_base@} \,\text{cm}\) (side of the pentagon)
  • \(\text{Slant height }= {@slant@}\, \text{ cm}\) (distance from centre O to a vertex).

To find the area of the above pentagon the following steps are followed

\(\textbf{ Step 1. Find the area of one triangle.}\)

Each triangle is isosceles, but we can split it into two right-angled triangles to find its height.

Base\(= {@base_length @} \,\text{cm}\)

Hypotenuse \(= {@slant@}\, \text{ cm}\)

height \(=\) ?

Use Pythagoras’ theorem to find the perpendicular height (h).

\(\begin{align} {@slant@}^2 &= h^2+({@half_base@})^2 \\ {@slant1@}&=h^2 + {@half_base1@} \\ h^2 &= {@slant1@}-{@half_base1@} \\ h&=\sqrt{{@height_1@}}\\ &={@height@} \\ &={@height3@} \\ & \approx {@height2@} \end{align}\)

\(\text{Step 2. Calculate area of one triangle.}\)

\( \begin{align} \text{Area} &= \frac{1}{2} \times \text{base} \times \text{height} \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \times {@base_length@} \times {@height2@} \\ &=\frac{1}{2} \times {@area_1@} \\ &={@area_triangle1@}\, \text{cm}^2 \end{align}\)

\(\textbf{Step 3. Calculate area of the pentagon.}\)

\( \begin{align} \text{Area}&= 5 \times \text{Area of one triangle}\\ &= 5 \times {@area_triangle1@}\\ &= {@area_pentagon@}\\ &={@ta@}\,\text{cm}^2 \end{align}\)

Area of the pentagon \({@ta@}\,\text{cm}^2\).
